intro: Acaena glabra var. heterantha, commonly known as the hairy spinney, is a low-growing shrub native to New Zealand. It features small, yellowish flowers that appear in clusters, typically during the spring and summer months. The plant produces tiny, spiny fruits that contain edible seeds, which are often consumed by birds and other wildlife. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and covered in fine hairs, giving it a distinctive textured appearance. This species thrives in coastal and subalpine habitats, where it plays an important ecological role.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena glabra var. heterantha is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the northern and central regions of the country. This plant typically grows in coastal and lowland areas. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils. It is commonly associated with coastal dunes and open vegetation.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena glabra var. heterantha was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the colonial period. This plant has since become naturalized in various regions of the country. It is commonly found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. Its introduction has led to its spread in both coastal and inland areas.
